definition: Third-party organization or vendor that obtains, maintains, uses, or discloses customer information on behalf of financial institution, including processors, servicers, software providers, cloud providers, consultants, and other business partners. Subject to GLBA Safeguards Rule and Privacy Rule requirements through contractual obligations.
official_description: Under GLBA Section 501(b) and Safeguards Rule 16 CFR 314.4(f), financial institution must ensure that service providers with access to customer information implement and maintain GLBA-equivalent safeguards. Service provider definition: any person (other than financial institution) that maintains, processes, or otherwise is permitted access to customer information or confidential business information by institution in connection with providing service to institution. Service provider examples: payment processors, check processors, data centers, cloud service providers, backup vendors, software providers, IT consultants, accounting firms, legal firms handling customer matters, business process outsourcing (BPO) vendors, collection agencies, loan servicers, credit reporting agencies, fraud detection vendors, security assessment firms, business continuity vendors. Service provider data security obligations: implement information security program with GLBA-equivalent safeguards; maintain safeguards appropriate to data sensitivity and institution's risk; use customer information only as authorized; provide breach notification; allow institution audit rights; manage sub-contractors (sub-vendors); cooperate in incident response. Financial institution retains ultimate responsibility for service provider safeguards (cannot delegate compliance obligation). Service provider relationship documented in service provider agreement specifying security and privacy obligations. Institution must conduct pre-engagement due diligence on vendor security; ongoing monitoring of vendor compliance; remediation of non-compliance; vendor off-boarding procedures.
applicable_to: All financial institutions using service providers; any vendor with customer information access; processors, servicers, cloud providers, consultants, software providers; vendors processing any type of customer information (financial data, NPI, payment card data, health information); vendors managing critical systems; all service provider types (IT, BPO, professional services, etc.)

definition: Sub-vendor or further contractor engaged by service provider to process or have access to customer information. Service provider responsible for subcontractor oversight and GLBA compliance. Financial institution may extend audit rights to subcontractors. Chain of data responsibility extends through all vendor tiers.
official_description: Under GLBA Safeguards Rule 16 CFR 314.4(f), service provider responsibility includes oversight of subcontractors. Subcontractor definition: person or entity engaged by service provider (not directly by financial institution) to perform functions involving customer information or critical systems. Subcontractor examples: cloud provider's IT support vendors, payment processor's backup vendors, data center provider's security contractors, software vendor's support vendors, IT vendor's sub-contractors for specialized functions. Service provider (primary vendor) responsible for: identifying subcontractors; assessing subcontractor security; requiring equivalent safeguards; conducting ongoing monitoring; ensuring breach notification; managing sub-vendor non-compliance. Financial institution rights: institution may audit subcontractors directly (typically with service provider coordination); institution may demand remediation of subcontractor non-compliance; institution may require replacement of subcontractors; institution retains ultimate responsibility (cannot delegate to service provider alone). Subcontractor chain: responsibility cascades through vendor tiers - each vendor must manage next tier of vendors; no vendor can claim lack of direct relationship absolves them of oversight; financial institution may reach down multiple vendor tiers for safeguards verification.

definition: Critical or important business function delegated to external service provider, where provider operates function on behalf of institution but institution retains responsibility for compliance, service quality, risk management, and regulatory obligations. Outsourced functions require heightened oversight.
official_description: Under GLBA and banking regulator guidance (Interagency Guidance on Third-Party Relationships), outsourced function is business function essential to institution's operations or critical to customer services, managed by external provider but institution retains accountability. Outsourced function examples: data processing and mainframe operations, payments processing (ACH, wire, check), loan servicing and administration, deposit account processing, investment account administration, customer service and call centers, IT operations and infrastructure, information security operations (SOC/MSSP), backup and disaster recovery, human resources functions (payroll, benefits), accounting and financial reporting services. Outsourced function characteristics: critical to operations; affects customer experience; impacts regulatory compliance; involves significant customer information; performance directly reflects on institution; financial institution cannot delegate regulatory compliance; must maintain oversight and control; must ensure service quality; must ensure security; must ensure continuity. Service provider relationship for outsourced function: requires comprehensive service provider agreement; requires detailed service level agreements (SLAs); requires regular reporting and performance monitoring; requires right to audit and assess; requires redundancy and continuity planning; requires incident reporting; requires periodic testing and validation; institution may also require: financial stability assessment; key personnel continuity; alternative provider contingency; business continuity and disaster recovery.
applicable_to: Financial institutions outsourcing critical functions; any business unit outsourcing operations; payments function operators; data processing centers; loan servicers; custodians; IT operations providers; any vendor handling critical function; service providers acting as outsourcing partners; applies to all institution sizes; large institutions often have multiple outsourced functions; small institutions may outsource most operations
